Posts.Content: I used cold cap throughout and remain pleased I did. It doesn't actually take much longer as you have to hang around whilst they put lines in and get drugs from pharmacy etc. I had a wig fitted and ready to go - matched exactly to my style and colour so I coudl make the cahnge without anyone really noticing. My hair thinned and was a bit patchy for a few weeks when I did use my wig but I didn't come anywhere near losing it all. My hair started regrowing over thinned patches after I swopped from FEC to Taxotere and was soon at a point where I could have it restyled and highlighted so it looked like a conscious decision to have a new hairdo. It is cold ( take a couple of paracetemol half hour beforehand to stop headaches), wrap up in a blanket/woolly jumper and take a flask of hot drink. Take a large towel for around your shoulders so that you don't spend a couple of hours with freezing drips down your back and soaking clothes. You may have to be quite assertive to ensure the nurses leave it long enough before starting teh chemo infusion and leave it on long enough. Many don't believe it makes much difference ( although all the research suggests otherwise) and try to skimp on timings, thinking they are doing you a favour. I woud say if you are willing to persevere give it a go. Don't give up at first sign of hair dropping in shower and you will get back to looking like you a whole lot quicker. For me it was important I didn't look different - I wanted to work through chemo, be me for the kids and not tell that many people I was having treatment. Hair is the most obvious outward sign and it mattered a lot to me. I really couldn't do the 'cancer patient' look - I would have been treated differently at work and I didn't want that to happen. People say all sortsd of thinsg ' it will grow back quickly" " It's what is on teh inside that matters" etc etc and they are right but if hair and your image is important to you then try to minimise the impact of cancer treatment. Buy a decent eyeliner to make up for the eyelashes you shed too. Hope it goes OK for you, Tess x

Posts.Content: Hi, Thinning can be related to Tamoxifen but not usually slow regrowth - not sure how long it normally takes as I used cold cap and didn't go bald. just patchy and am now more or less back to normal with extensions. When I was researching to try and preserve/encourage hair I discovered that far from using 'chemical free' organic type shampoos we should be using good old fashioned head and shoulders - high zinc levels encourage hair growth. They have one out called endurance which actively promotes growth. It also releives itchy scalp a bit. I suffered horribly with this and wanted soemthing to stop me looking like I had nits as I was scratching all the time and this, of course, can break the weakened hair shafts. Other than that, avoid direct sunlight but do keep scalp warm to ecourage blood supply and therefore growth. If you can afford a silk pillow case, it reduces hair breakage from friction. I seem to be curlier now than pre-chemo so it looks shorter than it actually is. I'm sure it will come soon through - although maybe not exactly as before for a while. It does drag the whole breast cancer experience out a bit. Tess x

Posts.Title: breast lump and scared

Posts.Content: Hello Fivejays, What a worrying time for you. I am convinced it is worse for partners than it is for the person going through it. The pre-op will do blood tests to make sure the blood count is fine for an operation and that their aren't any underlying things to worry about like diabetes that hasn't been diagnosed. She may have a chest x ray as this will show up most lung abnormalities and any problem with an enlarged heart or other chest infections etc. I didn't have CT scan for breast cancer as had already had loads for a lung condition. I don't think they are routine unless and abnormality is picked up on chest xray ( as lung secondaries would generally, be). CT scans are not without risk. It is thought my breast cancer was triggered by having to have lots of CT scans to the chest for a serious lung problem...The tumour grading isn't done until after it has been removed - the biopsy only gives an indication and the grading can change across the tumour. Mine was a mix of grade 2 and 3. When they have all the information from histology they put it in to an online tool called adjuvent online and this predicts how effective the treatments will be. It gives recurrence and survival rates based on your particular circumstances such as grade, lymph node involvement, underlying conditions, age etc. It also compares the rates if various treatments are completed either singly or individually and this helps the team decide whether the risks outweigh the benefits. He will also have had many years of clinical experience and would have a good idea about spread. Luckily your partners tumour is small. The outcomes for lumpectomy are as good as the outcomes for mastectomy but obviously you heal both physically and emotionally a lot better from the former. If she does have chemo she might find her Crohns improves as it is autoimmune in origin and the immune system is suppressed by the chemo. I have Lupus and felt better than I had for years when I finished chemo. Hope all goes well. Tess x

Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and Calcium Supplements

Posts.Content: I've had several bronchoscopies due to having dodgy lungs prior to breast cancer. They usually give you a sedative as it is quite a hard procedure to relax with otherwise ( someone looming over you and shoving a tube down your throat). With the sedative it is fine. You wear own clothes throughout but are likely to have a little monitor put on your finger to show oxygen levels. Then they put cannula in hand and give some sedative - good feeling. You think you know what is going on but don't really remember it or care. They freeze the back of your throat with a spray and tehn they put the tube down into your lungs. They may just look through the camera or they may take small biopsies. It doesn't hurt. Afterwards you need a few hours to come around and have to wait until your swallow reflex returns. I've always gone home the same day and been back at work next day. If you are planned for late in the day you might need to stop over.
Posts.Title: Bronchoscopy........

Posts.Content: Delighted the scans were clear. Don't panic about the chemo as Debra says it is nowhere near as bad as you think it will be. I only had a total of 14 days off work throughout surgery, chemo and radio, I still managed the gym, lost nearly three stone (good thing!) and kept most of my hair. I had every side effect possible, I think - DVT's, neutropaenic sepsis, anaphylactic allergic reaction and it still wasn't that awful. It passes very quickly and so long as you are fairly organised with things like menu planning and freezing meals for the couple of days each cycle when you probably won't feel like cooking then it is very manageable. I am convinced that far from 'listening to our bodies and being gentle with ourselves that maintaining as normal a life as possible makes it easier. There is a really good side to having breast cancer - you certainly get to know yourself a whole lot better and probably your partner and friends better too. Tess x

Posts.Content: I decided to go ahead with chemo as for me it was a 'no brainer' not to, once I had seen what percentage difference the various treatments made to me personally. Chemo for me meant a 38% increased chance of survival at 5 years. I have children and didn't like the idea of 'popping my clogs' so quickly so decided I had to concur and accept my oncologists offer. I didn't 'sail through' exactly although the everyday side effects were much less of a problem than I thought they would be and I continued to work right through treatment. However I had an armful of DVT's and had to give myself anticoagulant injections on top of the GCSF jabs every day for six months. I had neutropaenic sepsis twice and had to be admitted for IV antibiotics but soon got over this. I am well passed the hair regrowth stage now but am left with some permanant damage. One arm is bigger than the other from the effects of the DVT's - it is also a different colour and gets funny muscle spasms from time to time. I have had to swop my wedding ring to the other hand as it gets so swollen sometimes. I must be one of the few people who get what amounts to lymphoedema in the 'good' arm. Also, I am under the Brompton for some other lung problem and it now seems I have early heart failure probably due to chemo. This may affect my long term survival but has also given me a good hard kick and I am now obsessive about the exercise and healthy eating that I gave lip service to before. I am probably fitter than I have been for years and people tell me I look better, too. I am certainly more willing to take risks and have a more interesting life. Heart failure can be kept at bay nowadays and I can do much to stay on top of it. Breast cancer left without chemo would almost certainly have killed me much quicker. If I needed chemo again, would I ? Almost certainly. I also have two quite bad scars from radio, one on my boob and one on my neck that does show but I guess this is a small price to pay. The time when it impacts most really does pass very quickly. Other things can be dealt with as and when they appear. Tess x
Posts.Title: Concerns about chemo

Posts.Content: They can't give a definite grading until the lump is out but a best guess based on biopsy results. A grade one is the lease aggressive of all tumours so the rate of spread is slow. Whether it has spread to the lymph nodes will depend on how long it has been there and how large the tumour is. A grade one is very good news. Most women survive breast cancer these days. The most usual route of spread is to the lymph nodes in the armpit on the affected side. I suspect your sister may be offered a sentinel node biopsy where they inject a blue dye and see which lymph nodes it has spread to then just remove one or two and check it hasn't spread to them. If they are affected then more are often removed to reduce risk of recurrence or wider spread. If it seems likely that there is spread to the lymph nodes these may be removed by surgery in the armpit. It is rare for it to have spread elsewhere if it hasn't spread to the lymph nodes. I had bone scan and liver scan prior to surgery as mine was a higher grade. I don't think everyone does. If it is a small grade one tumour and in a 'good' place then a lumpectomy followed by radiotherapy for about six weeks is the usual treatment. The surgery is Ok really and I still like my boobs afterwards. I can still wear any skimpy bra and swimming costumes etc without any problem. My surgeon told me to bring in my tiniest bra on the day of surgery so she could check she mae the scar under the bra line. Recovery was quick and I went back to work in a few days. I did have a drain under my arm where the surgery to remove my lymph nodes was. This was fine but wouldn't have been a good look at work. Your sister may not even need as much as this and may just have day surgery and a see through waterproof dressing. Hope all goes well. Tess x

Posts.Content: I had 3 FEC and 3 Tax before radio and Tamoxifen. I am a bit older than you at 46 but my periods didn't stop properly at all through chemo. I had spotting to the end. My oncologist said it was because I had high oestrogen levels and my body was continually battling the chemo. I then had two fairly normal periods and then two months of spotting here and there once on tamoxifen. They have stopped completely now since about March/April time. I assumed menopaussal so talked to surgeon about contraception (she is the most sensible of my consultants). She did a hormone level test and it came back 'normal' ie although oestrogen levels low because of Tamoxifen, my FSH levels are still high so can still produce eggs so still need contraception. She said she was amazed and like me had I assumed it had triggered the menopause. I still have really hot moments at night sometimes. I would try not to worry too much - it has to be a really, really low chance of a cervical cancer and a breast cancer one after the other. Plus chemo would assumably have blasted any possible nasty cells in your nether regions. Tess x

Posts.Content: Wine doesn't affect oestrogen receptor positive tumours any more than others. There is a definite link between excess alcohol consumption and many cancers including breast cancers - it is an indirect link (eg might be that highly calorific alcohol users tend to be heavier and obesity is linked to increased cancer risk). I spoke to my oncologist who laughed and said go enjoy the odd glass of wine - she must have known how awful wine tasted once you are on chemo. I found ice cold lager did the trick instead! Exercise conversely, reduces the risk of cancer return significantly - well done to those who have managed the gym. I am sure the only reason I managed to work throughout treatment was because using the gym meant I actually reduced the fatigue levels. Tess x

Posts.Content: I am by no means a gym junky but I realised that I wanted to remain as normal as possible for my kids sake and that exercise was key to beating fatigue due to chemo and the best way or preventing recurrence. I carried on going to the gym three times a week - there were a couple of days each cycle when I couldn't and a couple of times I had neutropaenic sepsis I had to miss a few days. I also got loads of DVT's and had to miss a few days then too. It was sometime quite hard to motivate myself against the overwhelming tiredness towards the end of chemo but when I did get up and get going I always felt much better. I believe that it was the gym that allowed me to continue to work through chemo, too. People say 'listen to your body' but we have to remember it is not our bodies speaking but the chemo. I went to the gym four days after surgery too and have not had any complications at all - not underarm tightness or arm restrictions, no lymphodoema etc. There is really interesting research around a group of women with breast cancer who took up dragon boating post surgery and who despite vigourous exercise and long haul flights, have never had lymphodoema. I also used the cold cap - really long hair might be better cut shorter but you don't have to give yourself a 'number one' or short back and sides. Take paracetemol half hour before treatment to prevent headaches, have a towel for around your shoulders to stop icy water dripping down your back, a flask of hot drink and trashy magazines - it is hard to concentrate on proper reading. The best advice I can give is persevere - your hair will fall out in what looks like huge amounts, it will thin but as soon as you start Taxotere it will probably start growing back over the thinned areas and you will be back to normal far quicker and can get on with not being a cancer patient sooner. Tess x

I think it is good to weigh up exactly how much difference it will make in your specific circumstances - you roncologist can tell yo this from the diagnsotic tool, Adjuvent online. Tess x

I now have one arm bigger than the other, a different colour to the other and all lumpy - and that is my good arm! I ws in hospital earlier this year and needed IV's for scans etc but they couldn't get a line in so the radiologist said he would put a line in my node less arm. I kicked up. He told me I was 'being silly' that he was ' a consultant and knew about these things and it was perfeclty safe'. I pointed out he was a 'locum' for a reason and I was happy to go along with his plan after I had spoken to my surgeon. He refused to let me have the scan and sent me back to the ward where a delighful, patient registrar coaxed my veins to the surface, inserted a cannula and then sorted my scan out.Mt surgeon came to visit me and said I had been right to refuse as I ran significant risk of damage if the veins in that arm were traumatised. Posts.Content: Jet, I am sorry about your second diagnosis and understand completely your anguish at telling the husband and family. I was already having tests for throat cancer when my breast cancer was diagnosed - although Thank God, it isn't cancer just another vocal chord problem. As a result of the investigations into these I had a chest x-ray which was abnormal so was referred to a chest physician who ruled out most things ( I was tested for AIDS, lung cancer, lymphoma all manner of wierd and wonderful diseases to no avail). I had repeated CT scans which continued to show problems and was eventually referred to Brompton just before Christmas for lung biopsy. It was suggested I had a condition that is almost invariably fatal within four or five years. I too baulked at putting family through more stress and decided to 'wait and see' outcome. When I had to tell them they were furious that I had deceived them and not told the entire truth. This was far more stressful than the potential diagnosis. Since then I decided to make sure my lungs were as fit as possible and started running/swimming etc. I had more tests just yesterday and they show a very significant improvement - which means I can't possibly have the progressive disease they talked about. We have booked a holiday in Africa for Easter and are almost at the point of opening champagne . If I still hadn't told them they would not be able to share my joy at seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. I think you have to trust them and talk! It made my life easier in so many ways. They have survived and even grown through the process. My relationship with my husband is even better as it has made us realise how much we mean to each other. I am delighted it is benign but really, genuinely sorry you have to go through this as well. I hope all turns out OK and the recovery is both swift and complete. Like you I am also wanting extensions - not sure how to go about it and how long hair has to be. I used cold cap so have a decent ( ish) covering of longer hair and a few thinner patches that need covering before I will wear my head in public. Hope all goes well - somehow we do find the strength within ourselves. Tess x

Posts.Content: Hello, The multi disciplinary team will use all your results and decide which treatment options are best in your given situation after they have the histology results from your surgery. If you have a lump removed then you will almost certainly be offered radiotherapy which does involve daily travel to a centre with linear accelerators, the machines they use for radio. I had seven weeks Mon to Friday but some places offer shorter courses. Chemo will depend on outcome of histology - but is still quite likely. You have a chemo day every three weeks and recovery time in between. I worked through chemo and so do plenty of others with a couple of days off each cycle. Your employer may help by allowing you to do some work from home, allowing part time hours or more gently duties - many are kindly disposed towards people on chemo. I found working an excellent distraction and actually felt better for doing something other than lying around being treated like a victim by well intentioned friends. Speak to your breast care nurse about transport to the hospital for radio and chemo - may are entitled to transport via volunteer drivers or ambulance service or at least have their costs paid. They can also help with money situations generally, as can Macmillan who can either give hardship grants or sound advice. I had three days off for the surgery then worked from home for a couple of days as I still had drains in under my arm - otherwise felt fine. Good luck with surgery. Tess x

Posts.Content: I used cold cap throughout and am delighted I did. It is five months since I finished chemo and my hair is nearly back to normal - shoulder length and thick. It wasn't pleasant. I got disheartened during cycle three when some started falling out and hair thinned in patched meaning I had to get the wig out. It took longer each time I went for chemo ( although most people seemed to take ages anyway). It stopped feeling so awful about ten minutes after it is put on as your head just goes numb. It does let you retain some control. It does work for most people who persevere. Ignore stuff about special organic shampoos - just a way of parting you from your money and certainly no evidence it works. Ignore people who say cold cap doesn't work for FEC - research proves it does. Don't expect a complete miracle, some loss will occur but not the devastating total hairloss I was not prepared to deal with. Chemo isn't as bad as you imagine it is going to be and is over fairly quickly. As for portacath - I used plain old fashioned cannulation and my veins are rubbish. I had DVT's so it always took seven or eight attempts as a minimum but I am now glad I resisted PICC's and portacaths as I hated anything that made me look or feel more like a cancer 'victim'. I have two wigs an NHS one that is an expensive monofilament and which was completely free but was a tad too dark for my natural hair colour so I don't wear it at all. I also bought one from Trendco in Brighton which was a perfect match for the colour and style of my own hair so no-one noticed the transition. Tess x

Posts.Content: I'm further donw the road than you. Iposted earlir but for some reason unknown to me the moderators decided it needed to be looked at and haven't added it to the posts. I had my hair cut shorter about 8 weeks post chemo, as advised by my lovely hairdresser. It made it looked thicker and got rid of the straggly patchy look. It was shoulder length until then but she took a few inches off and then highlighted it for me so it looked like a postive choice to go different. Most colleagues did not know I was on chemo and I still got loads of compliments on my shorter (but nowhere near crew cut/ ultra short) hair. I was planning extensions at around three/four months but decided I liked my hair as it was and was happy to go without them. If you think about it, hair itself is dead already and just hangs there. it can be dried out and made more brittle by heat etc but chemicals inside us only affect the hair follicle not the hair. At end of chemo we need to be careful of pulling on hair roots to avoid further damage to fragile follicles but all this organic shampoo and expensive 'natural' stuff is just hogwash and placebo. I used head and shoulders throughout as it reduced itching and the zinc in it is proven to stimulate hair growth ( by research rather than old wives tales). It is such a nice feeling knowing that cold cap will be your last and that it is worth it. It is SO nice when you fell like your hair makes you look like you again. Enjoy! Tess x

Posts.Content: Hello, I am not sure where you got your statistics from - If you ask your oncologist or surgeon, they will print out a copy of a predictive prognostic indicator called adjuvent online. This is basically a system that takes all your specific circumstances into consideration and tells you your 5 year survival rate and 10 year recurrence rate and will give the rates with each of the treatments added in so you can see how much difference they make. I found mine very reassuring adn it made me realise that most of us recover from breast cancer with the amazing treatments available nowadays. I wonder if you have read the 5 year survival rate as 'we are only going to survive 5 years'. This is a common misconception. In fact it means that they only measure survival at five years because after this time, if there is no recurrence you are considered cured. It is a bit scary being diagnosed, the treatments though effective are hardly pleasant but we do get through it and come out the other side. Make sure you ask for hard data about your specific circumstances before going into blind panic. Tess x

Posts.Content: The Er +ve 6/6 is a good thing - it measn the tumour is quite highly oestrogen receptor positive. This more or less means it is 'fuelled' oestrogens and recurrence/spread can be managed by limiting the amount of oestrogen a women is producing or by blocking the bits on the tumour that the oestrogen locks on to. It is likely to mean your mother will be given wither tamoxifen or Arimadex. In addition, it is Herceptin receptor positive which means that herceptin will be effective in minimising spread/recurrence. Your mum has two drugs that are going to be effective in ensuring here cancer is manageable. Lucky women! (Not sure she will be feeling this at teh moment though). The PCT can no longer refuse to fund herceptin so although there may be a few days wait for it to be authorised she will get it. Tess x

Posts.Content: Unless in the private wing of an NHS hospital I would avoid private for anything serious. Thet are generally fine for elective hip replacements etc but they just don't have staff with the same knowledge and experience that the NHS cancer units have. Yes you will have a single room and choice of wine at supper but you will also have a 'chemo nurse specialist' who has only done a weeks course on the subject and a RMO (Resident Medical Officer - the junior doctor who does everything in most private hospitals, often South African or Australian on a six month career trip). Outside of the consultants rounds your care is left to inexperienced people who will have seen very few people with cancer of any sort. There are no support services such as the wig ladies/the support groups/the looking good courses/mac nurses and no 24 hour emergency number. If you become ill you generally have to be transferred to the NHS anyway. There are one or two places that have the facilities and staff to provide reasonable oncology care (such as Cromwell and Harley Street Clinic) but otherwise I would definitely steer clear. Tess x

Posts.Content: I would completely disagree with two posts above. Mastectomy is serious surgery with a much longer recovery time and possibly very long term emptional impact. The outcomes for lumpectomy and mastectomy in terms of survival are exactly the same. I would say you need more professional information so you can make an informed choice rather than rely on other peoples anxieties to drive you towards mastectomy. Ask your surgeon for a print out of adjuvent online the predicitive tool that shows the risks for you personally with various treatment options. It can tel you what difference chemotherapy makes, for instance and weigh up the difference (or probably no difference) between mastectomy and lumpectomy. If you have no nodal spread you are in a very good position and odds or recurrence or not surviving are quite low assuming it is not a triple negative tumour. Do not be frightened into a mastectomy. I was so pleased muy surgeon threw my husband out ot the consultation when he kept on about 'getting rid of it all' and put heavy pressure on for a mastectomy. My surgeon was adamant I would do much better with lumpectomy and axillary node clearance. It reduces risk of lymphoedema and other complications such as serious infections and it is really very minor surgery so you are in a much better place to start any other treatment. Tess x

Posts.Content: Hi Jeanette, I had wide local excision two days after you with axillary clearance due to affected nodes. My surgeon was really good and luckily I was more or less back to normal a couple of days later - albeit with a tennis ball sized seroma that resolved witout intervention and didn't cause any problems. On the follow up my surgeon gave me the histology report and also turned her computer around to show me in detail the statistics for me personally on her prognostic indicator database. These includedd five and ten year survival rates, recurrence rates and the difference various treatements made - she put in about three different chemo regimes to come up with the best option for me. As a combined course or chemp/radio/hormonal therapies increases five year survival by about 29% I'd be mad not to accept the offer. The way I look at it is that I should be extremely grateful I have ready, free, access to some of the best healthcare in the world. In most countries I would not be offered these potent drugs or would be denied them if I couldn't afford to pay. As it is, I get what is best for me regardless of cost, at a centre quite close to my home. I even get money towards a wig and a special clinic to help me chose one. It seems churlish to complain about side effects given the drugs will hopefully mean I can watch not only my children but my grandchildren graduate. I think everyone should be shown their specific statistics on the predictive prognostic tool as it certainly made the decision into a non-event in my case. Tess x

Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and muscle cramps

Posts.Content: I think you are going to h ave to be very assertive here - don't throw away your chances of a family through timidity. You need to speak again to your oncologist as a matter of urgency and explain that you are very concerned and wish to preserve your chances of becoming a mother as much as possible. If need be insist on a referral to a fertility specialist. Ask again why zoladex is unsuitable - it is usually prescribed for women who want ot preserve their fertility and who have oestrogen receptor positive tumours ( which yours is if you are going to have tamoxifen). Zoladex is used to temporarily dampen the ovaries whilst having active treatment and is reversible. Surgical removal or irradiation are not reveresible. Ask for a second opinion if necessary. Sounds like they think saving your life is the important bit ( which it is) and are paying less consideration to the holistic treatment of you as a person. Kick up quickly and loudly until either measures are put in place to preserve your fertility or they properly explain why this is not possible. I wish you every success - this is a bad enough place to be at our age without causing you further distress. Tess x

Yes I lost all body hair - everywhere - meant I didn't have to wax or shave legs for ages and had to invest in eyeliner to disguise loss of eyelashes (works quite well and stops the 'cancer patient look' I so detest). I started wearing more lippy too to change focus of face and disguise sallow skin. Body hair came out about cycle three, I think, but was thinning before then. I got a bit uncomfortable in some areas where all hair was lost so invested in some granny knickers to stop skin on skin rub. Husband quite pleased with regrowth - all lovely and soft - I shall say no more on that subject though! Eyelashes nearly back to normal now and I can wear mascara to boost them a bit ( had to re-learn skill from my teenage daughter). It has made me realise I am more vain than I thought I was and made me give far more attention to my appearance than I had been doing. I even got chatted up the other day - and that hasn't happened for so long that I'd forgotten how nice it feels. Tess x

Posts.Content: That isn't quite right - Zoladex (like Tamoxifen and anything else that reduces oestrogen like surgical oophrectomy and irradiation of ovaries) would reduce effectiveness of chemo if given at the same time. This is because the chemo attacks rapidly dividing cells like cancer and ovaries and lining of mouth. If oestrogen is reduced it reduces ability of chemo to attack cancer so higher levels are maintained during chemo and then sledgehammered after chemo with Tamoxifen/zoladex/irraditation and surgery. Zoladex should be used after chemo to suppress oestrogen in women who wish to maintain fertility - although it won't help with the effects chemo may have on your ability to conceive at a later date. It is often given to women who can't tolerate Tamoxifen for some reason and need to use arimadex or similar. I think it would still be worth speaking to a fertility specialist ASAP as there are so many things that can be done to boost chances of conception in women with reduced fertility. I think you should make sure you are doing all ou can to protect yourself. On a personal note - I kept having periods all through chemo and only stopped once on the Tamoxifen, so may not be quite as dire as you are now thinking as long as you don't have any permanent method or suppressing ovarian function. Tess x
